section.title: Contents of the Distribution
section.para: The ToscanaJ distribution consists of a single compressed file containing all the files needed to run ToscanaJ and the editor for ToscanaJ-files, Elba. The compressed file contains the following files and directories:

section.title: Installing and Running ToscanaJ
section.para: ToscanaJ runs on every Java 1.4 Standard Edition (SE) enabled platform. At the time of writing this includes Windows, Linux (x86) and a range of different Solaris versions. Other platforms have announced support for Java 1.4 SE, most noticably MacOS X. Please make sure your system supports Java 1.4 SE before installing ToscanaJ.

Assuming Java is set up properly, ToscanaJ needs no special installation procedure, extracting the contents of the distribution into some read and write
Write access is required only onto the file toscanaj.prop accessible location is sufficient. Afterwards ToscanaJ and Elba can be started using the appropriate batch or shell scripts for the platform, e.g. run-toscanaj.bat for running ToscanaJ on a Windows computer or run-elba.sh for running Elba on a Linux/Unix computer. In case your platform is not supported by the scripts but does run Java 1.4 SE, please let us know. You should still be able to run the programs by executing a commands to the ones in the scripts.

section.title: Configuration Options
section.para: ToscanaJ tries to reduce the user interface by not offering too many options to the standard user. Since the program is applicable in a wide range of domains, its desired behaviour can be quite different, though. This fact is accomodated by having a range of configuration options which are accessible by adding/changing parameters in the properties file toscanaj.prop. These options are described in the following sections.

Capitalization is relevant, i.e. all names have to use exactly the same spelling. Colors are given as six hexadecimal digits in the same way as they are in an HTML file, although the leading hash symbol has to be escaped with a backslash (see example below). Boolean values are turned on by setting the value to "1".

section.title: User Interface Options
section.para: Some options can be used to change the features available in ToscanaJ's main window. These are (given with their full keys):

section.title: Debug Options
section.para: A last set of options can be used to understand what happens behind the scenes. These are not supposed to be used in normal ToscanaJ system, but included for completeness.
